description:
The game “Underwood” reminds you of a simple card game based on its game mechanic but the actual point of it is to form words using letters, sort of like “Scrabble”. “Underwood” has a much more “intellectual-educational tint” compared to normal card games and a much more dynamic gameplay than “Scrabble”: words are easier to form, there are more unexpected events in the game and a lot less stress.

At the beginning of the game each player receives 7 cards. The deck is placed on the table, one card is drawn and placed next to it, this will be the beginning of the “tape”. Players then take turns.

A players turn consist of:
• Draw three cards from the deck,
• If possible form a word using the cards from your hand and placing it before you,
• Place one of his remaining cards to the “tape”.

Each player during his turn adds one card to the “tape”, this way the “tape” becomes longer. If a player needs a certain letter to form a word but doesn’t have them he can take them from the “tape”, he also takes the remaining letters following the one he took.

The “Underwood” card — a free card. Can replace any letter in played word. You can take the “Underwood” card used by another player by replacing it with the letter it was used as. “Underwood” cannot be placed on the “tape”.

Prize cards can be played together with a word if the word fits the cards criteria (for example, is a piece of clothing, none of the letters repeat). The prize card increases the points for that word and can give a player some extra possibilities.

When a player “leaves” (has no cards left to play at the end of his turn or only has prize cards), the round ends and points are counted. Points for a players word are calculated based on the letter cost of that word (each letter is worth a certain amount of points) and prize card used. The cost of letters that remain on the players hands is deducted from his point total. It is possible to get a negative result due to this.

Points earned during a round sum up with points gained on previous rounds. The game is played until one player earns the necessary amount of points to win (the amount of points should be decided before starting the game). The first one to earn them is the winner.

This game contains: 
• 102 letter-cards; 
• 14 prize cards;
• 4 “Underwood” cards; 
• Game rules.

More about cards
A letter card, apart from the letter also has its cost shown (how points a player gains from using it in his word) and the number of cards in the deck with this letter.

A prize card has: an icon, conditions to play this card and the prize that it gives. The icon shows what the card requirements are. There is also a more detailed explanation on what needs to be done.

Party game. 12 cards are placed around the house, each card having a cryptic clue to a subject sketched on it.

Example: a phrase;
An M in the top left corner
A T in the top right corner
A rabbit's head in the middle
An E in the bottom left corner
A D in the bottom right corner
Answer = Empty Headed (MT Head ED)

The player who gets the most right, wins.

This Mega Bloks Dominoes Build game challenges players to match cards with colors and animals to win block pieces. The first player to collect all four animal block pieces and build their zoo friend wins.

Oversized blocks and cards are perfect for little hands.
Details:
        Includes: 30 cards & 16 Mega Bloks
        Ages 3 years & up
        For 2 to 4 players

(website)

A target shooting game with some humour. Just look at the outlaw target, shooting his own foot.

Here are the complete rules:

WILD WEST SHOOTING GALLERY
Here we have four lawless characters from way out in the Wild West, at present in a gay mood. Little do they know that the Sheriff’s posse is hot on their trail.
Why not join the Sheriff and his men and try your skill at shooting these rascals down?
HOW TO PLAY
Stand the target in the slotted wooden blocks at the sides of the box, then place it at a distance of four to five feet from the players.
Hold gun in your right hand and insert the metal end of the dart into the muzzle, resting rubber head of dart against palm of left hand, press home dart until spring “clicks" into loaded position.
Play can be for a pre-arranged total score, the first player reaching such score being the winner, or for a certain number of rounds, the highest scorer being the winner, 2nd and 3rd highest runners-up.

ΠοιÏŒς ΠοÏ ΠÏŒτε ΓιατÎ¯? (Who Where When Why?) contains 3.600 questions with their answers, concerning history, geography, arts, animals/plants, sports and science.
The players roll the dice and move on the board, answer the questions and continue to move as long as they are correct. First to make it to the "exit" wins.


ΠεριÎ­χει 3.600 ερωτÎ®σεις μαζÎ¯ με τις απαντÎ®σεις τους γÏρω απÏŒ ιστορÎ¯α, γεωγραφÎ¯α, γρÎ¬μματα και τÎ­χνες, ζÏŽα και φυτÎ¬, αθλητισμÏŒ, επιστÎ®μες. Οι παÎ¯κτες παÎ¯ζουν πÎ¬νω στο ταμπλÏŒ, απαντοÏν σε ερωτÎ®σεις και τσεκÎ¬ρουν τις απαντÎ®σεις με σκοπÏŒ να φτÎ¬σουν πρÏŽτοι στην Î­ξοδο.

In Mindstein, each player takes a turn as the reader, reading a card with five multiple choice questions. Where Mindstein differs from a run-of-the-mill trivia game is that each multiple choice question has three answers corresponding to three different letters; the correct answers for each question spell a five letter word that players compete to be the first to yell out.

If you get the five letter word first, you get to draw a letter from the draw pile; first to spell "S-M-A-R-T" wins!

Board Game based on Athletic Disciplines

You will enjoy a real board game where athletic events are simulated on a track and field. Such as 100/200/400 metres, 110 metres hurdles, 4x100 metres, long, high and triple jump, and throwing events including: javelin, hammer discus and shot put.
The goal is to achieve the highest score in the different athletic disciplines that are considered before the event.

The board represents the field and running track. On the track disciplines are developed throws and jumps, and on the track racing. The players will use 2/5 dice of different colors, depending on how many of the same discipline to develop. Difficulties in the disciplines are taken into account with one of the dice to use. In each discipline each player (athlete) will move its piece on the board in the room or location that corresponds to the number thrown with the dice and thereby indicate the regulations in each discipline.

The player who collected the most points at the end of the disciplines developed will be the winner of the competition.

Rahan is a French comics series about an intelligent prehistoric man, that appeared first as part of Pif gadget, then published in albums of 2 to 4 complete stories. It was initially written by Roger Lecureux, and after his death in 1999, by his son, Jean-François Lecureux. Most of the artwork is drawn by Andre Cheret, as well as some other artists (Enrique Romero, Zam, DeHuescar)..
In 1986, Rahan was adapted into an animated series.

The Game :
Each player have a Prehistoric cave man wich moves with movement cards.
They must reach "Fire" or "Water" area and bring them back to the cave.
They shoot at wild animals with the "silex".
They try to meet Rahan to recover an invention from him.

Objective: be the first ending your round trip through Brandenburg
 - acting by turn -
1. draw a starting card & 3 places/cards you have to visit 
2. form the best route connecting these places
3. travel along this route, draw (travel) cards (and use them to speed up), follow instructions (if any), read statements of places (sightseeing)...

Who will you invite to tea? Be careful who you invite as sometimes the characters will disappear as soon as they arrive!

In Tea Time, players collect characters from Lewis Carroll's Alice in Wonderland, and each character card (other than Alice) is double-sided, with a normal image on one side and a reverse "mirrored" image on the other. Each round, an array of characters is laid out, with normal and mirrored images alternating. The round's start player takes one character, adds it to his collection, then places the Alice card in that spot of the array. The next player takes 1-2 cards, but if he takes two, the cards must be adjacent. From the third player on, each player takes 1-3 cards; again, you can take multiple cards only if they're adjacent. If you ever have a normal and a mirrored image of the same character in your collection, *poof* they both disappear.

After five rounds (with two players) or three rounds (with 3-4 players), the game ends. Players score 1-15 points for collecting 1-5 cards of the same character – with zero cards of a character being worth five points, so sometimes you do want them to vanish! Alice herself is worth four points, and whoever has the most points wins.

Similar to Voyage en France.

Instead of receiving all destination cards in start of the game player draws a next card if he reaches one of destinations.

The players have to move along the board by throwing a die. 
First player who has visited 5 destination cities and arrives back in the Paris wins the game.

Kubbuteo is an indoor version of popular garden game, Kubb. Players take turns flicking 6 disks the length of a 4’ by 2’ board, trying to knock down their opponent’s Kubbs [upright disks]. The opponent flicks back the downed Kubbs and then have their turn at flicking the 6 disks at the Kubbs. Once a player has knocked down all Kubbs in the opponent’s half, they may attempt to knock down the centrally located King and thus win the game – but doing this beforehand will result in losing the game, so care must be taken.
 Kubbuteo can be played by people of all ages and appeals to players of Crokinole and Carrom, requiring the same dexterity skills. Tactically it is identical to parent game Kubb, deciding where to return downed Kubbs to.

User summary

A Japanese home-published tile/card game. The game starts with a setup of face down square tiles that have power lines on their face up side. Players choose one of the edge positions as their "exit" to empower, and take turns either turning up, rotating or echanging one of the earth tiles, with the goal of getting as many connected tiles as possible to their "exit". Once the exit has a set number of connected earth tiles, it's Sealed, and the first player to Seal four exits wins.

Players can also play cards from their hand for further effects.

Pluckin' Pairs embodies the same spirit as the classic party game Compatibility in that you want to match images with other players in order to score points, but the game play is more free form with everyone competing individually instead of in teams.

At the start of a round, eleven images are laid out on the table. All players secretly pair off images – say, coins and a manhole cover because they're both round, or a mirror and a building because they both reflect light – and write these pairs on their player sheet. One image will be leftover as the outcast.

After everyone has finished, you compare your pairs with those of other players. If no one – or conversely if everyone – created the same pair as you, you score no points for that pair. If only some of the players created that pair, each of those players scores as many points as the number of players who record the pair. (You can optionally compare outcast images as well, scoring points based on who had the same outcast as you.) The player with the most points after a certain number of rounds wins.

Objective: be the first bringing the treasure (to be found by you or others) back home
 - moving by turn - 
 - there's a treasure (= crystal) - in Hamburg or elsewhere -  hidden on the map (one of those flipped markers);
 - roll the dice, move & find it;
 - but prepare yourself in advance with counter/marker to escape (lightning) or defense/fighting ones, because your opponents are going to hunt you;
 - bring it back to your starting place in order to win.
Content:
1 board, 4 meeples, 36 marker/counter, 2 dice, rule sheet

The game board shows a map of Madrid. Players roll a die and move through the city, trying to reach the famous sites (especially those two whose cards they drew at the beginning and which are marked). Other means of transportation can be used to get around more quickly, but they have to be paid for in travel chips. When a player reaches a site, s/he is asked a question. If answering correctly, the site card can be discarded and a new travel chip is drawn. When reaching an unmarked site, they can earn a new site card (if that belongs to someone else, it can be "stolen").
When a player can reach both sites they drew at the beginning and gain two more site cards and return to their starting location, s/he wins the game.

Questions come in two difficulty levels, as the game is designed for language learning. So the difficulty does not refer to the knowledge needed to answer the question, but to the Spanish speaking ability.

The game board shows a map of Paris. Players roll a die and move through the city, trying to reach the famous sites (especially those two whose cards they drew at the beginning and which are marked). Additionally, taxis, buses and the tube can be used to get around more quickly, but they have to be paid for in travel chips. When a player reaches a site, s/he is asked a question. If answering correctly, the site card can be discarded and a new travel chip is drawn. When reaching an unmarked site, they can earn a new site card (if that belongs to someone else, it can be "stolen").
When a player can reach both sites they drew at the beginning and gain two more site cards and return to their starting location, s/he wins the game.

Questions come in two difficulty levels, as the game is designed for language learning. So the difficulty does not refer to the knowledge needed to answer the question, but to the French speaking ability.

Versability 'the poetry game' is a parlour game inspired by the Dictionary Game, where players complete a verse of poetry with missing line(s).  The players' attempts and the genuine version are read aloud and then the players vote on which is the genuine verse.

Rather than using cards, pieces and a board, Versability is published as a book.  Players need to provide paper and writing implements.  Randomness is achieved by closing one's eyes and pointing at a page of options.

A roll & move game for children in kindergarten, meant to educate them about the bad effects of bullying. Players roll a die and move their pawn. If they land on certain space they must draw a card. Players can choose whether to draw from the Friendship deck (moving them forward a few spaces) or the Bullying deck (moving them backwards a few spaces). The first player to reach space number 80 wins.

Objective:
find correct answers for questions out of the world of equestrian sport
- acting by turn -
decision: form 2 teams or act as 'lone fighters'
give fast & correct answers on questions like:
Horse racing: longest distance?
Western riding: dress regulations?
What is the meaning of 'hoofbeat'?

content:
50 cards with 150 questions, multiple-choice-answers and detailed explanations on the back of the cards
remarks:
game belongs to a series: 'Experten Quiz'

Objective:
find correct answers for questions out of the world of architecture 
- acting by turn -
decision: form 2 teams or act as 'lone fighters'
give fast & correct answers on questions like:
Who built the Guggenheim museum in NYC?
Which is the highest church in Germany?

content:
50 cards with 150 questions, multiple-choice-answers and detailed explanations on the back of the cards
remarks:
game belongs to a series: 'Experten Quiz'

Amoebas have escaped and are slithering around in all directions! Catch them fast!

In Panic Lab, the player-scientists have their hands full trying to figure out which amoeba to catch and where it might have oozed off to. To set up the game, shuffle the 25 cards, then lay them out in a circle.

At the start of a round, one player rolls four special dice which indicate the color, shape and pattern of the amoeba being sought as well as the color of the lab it left and in which direction it was traveling. Competing at the same time, players need to find the lab, then move in the right direction to spot the amoeba (which may, of course, be striped and not spotted).

But wait! If you encounter a vent after leaving the lab, you need to skip to the next vent in the circle before continuing your search. (Amoebas prefer to travel in the dark when possible.) Plus, if an amoeba passes through one of three mutation devices in the circle, you need to alter the criteria for your search, looking for a tentacled amoeba instead of one with a tail, for example, or an orange/red amoeba instead of a blue/purple one. Zap!

The first player to lay her hand on the correct card collects a token, and the first player to collect five tokens wins!

In Home Sweet Home, players have five diving bells and want to get as many sea creatures into them as possible – but crabs don't like octopi and vice versa, so keep those two species separate if you don't want trouble.

To set up the game, each player lays out diving bell cards in front of them, numbered 1-5, and receives four cards from the shuffled animal deck; crab and octopus cards are also numbered 1-5. At the start of a round, a player lays an animal card from her hand in the center of the table and states the sum of all cards played. The next player does the same, making sure that all animal cards are visible. This continues until the sum of the animals played totals twelve or more. The player who laid the last card takes the stack, then places the animals in her diving bells based on the number on the cards. If you would lay a crab in a diving bell that already holds one or more octopi cards (and vice versa), you must discard one card of each type.

Once the deck rounds out, players finish the round, if possible, then sum the animals in their diving bells. The player with the highest total wins!

Shepherds is a 2 players game (with 4 players variant) in which players try to catch 3 (of 9) sheep. They try to do it with one... dog. The first who do it, is a winner.

Each player has a set of cards. Players (alternately) play a card and move the dog to try herding the sheep into their pens. Cards have values from 1 to 5, which represent exactly how many spaces the dog must move.

The used card is discarded. If a player runs out of cards, all of that player's discarded cards return to their hand. At the end of the dog's movement, the player places a pen in his color on the dog's final square.

Players take turns one after the other in this way until the game ends.

In Speak Up!, everyone plays in one of five languages – German, English, French, Spanish or Italian – and not knowing the language won't necessarily be a detriment.

To set up the game, lay out 49 of the fifty cards on the table with the picture side faceup; next to the picture is the name of the item in five languages. The back of each card features the name of some other item in five languages.

To start play, take the card set aside during set-up and read one of the words on the back, say "Markt" (the German word for "market"). Everyone then races to find the card depicting the market, which will also have the various words for "market" next to the picture. Whoever finds it keeps the card, then flips it over and reads the German word on the back. This process continues until all the cards have been claimed. Whoever has the most cards wins!

To win Claim to Fame, you need to be the first team to move from start to finish by getting your team members to yell out five facts about celebrities and other famous people. Each round you have sixty seconds to deliver verbal hints, act out charades, draw clues – or all three – to aide teammates in guessing the facts listed on the back of your celebrity card.

Claim to Fame Travel Edition includes celebrity cards that can be used in the base game, while also being playable as a game on their own without the other components.

The goal in this card game is to climb up the career ladder to make as much money as possible. Each player is randomly assigned a profession at the start of the game; then a trick taking game is played in which each player holds six hidden cards plus some (depending on the number of players) cards which are drawn openly. The rank of the profession determines how players may talk to each others, mistakes are punished by penalty cards. After finishing a round, a player is demoted if s/he has more cards of the profession below him/her plus penalty cards. Promotions are then resolved as a result of demotions, and everybody gets their salary. The first player to own 100000 Euros is the winner.

Over a hundred years of legend awaits you and your skills as you vie to be the lucky prospector to hike out of the Superstition Mountains with The Lost Dutchman's Gold. However, this expedition for lost gold isn't for the faint of heart. You will face grizzly creatures and dastardly disasters around every corner and even the ghost of The Lost Dutchman himself while contending with your opponent's thirst for gold that grows with every nugget uncovered.

In this treacherous treasure adventure, prospectors must balance their skills to take on fierce creatures and dangerous disasters with their search of gold. Will you find the most treasure by prospecting or will the map lead you to victory? No one path guarantees victory but with the right amount of skill and a little bit of luck you can be the first prospector to uncover the famed Lost Dutchman's Gold!

Are you up to the challenge of uncovering the legendary gold of the Lost Dutchman?

The Lost Dutchman is a treasure mining game for 2-5 players in which players are competing to mine as much of the Lost Dutchman's Gold as they can before the water supply runs short bringing the hunt for treasure to a parching halt. Players can also win by successfully navigating the Community Treasure Map and finding the ever illusive Lost Dutchman's Gold Mine.

The object of the game is to mark the most points by forming "hands" of poker.

Everyone draws 5 cards and in his turn, arises from one to five of his cards on the board, to complement the "hands" of poker, interconnected as crosswords.

At the end of the game the scoring begins.
Player scores 2 to 42 points for poker combinations:
2 points per pair to 42 points per Royal Flush.

You need to get photos of the world to accomplish a story by answering questions.

Early in the game each player chooses a mission. Each mission is complete once player has recovered 5 photos matching the mission: 5 pictures of animals (one for each continent).

Each player moves his pawn on a game board representing the world by throwing two dice.

Next the box where it happens, he wins, loses or steals a photoby answering a question. If the answer just that question, you win the number of shots on the box (between one and three).

To win the game player must get 5 pictures related to his mission and finish her world tour.

Object of the game is to be the first players to have toured the multicultural France (central hexagon) and have successfully responded to the ultimate question.

Each player rolls the dice to determine his home community (Africa, Asia, No Paper, North Africa, France, Europe)

In his turn, a player rolls the dice and moves his pawn as many spaces. If it lands on a space issue, it must draw a card question and answer it before the end of the hourglass, otherwise it returns to its original square. If it lands on a space event, he must draw an event card and follow the instructions.

After answering a final question of his community, the game is won.

Objective: be the first to reach the target (field 70)
 - moving by turn -
‘Roll and Move’ game
move according die roll; ending on a marked space follow instructions glued on cover inside
Equipment: board, 6 meeples (can be extended up to 8), 1 die

Game play:
Each player takes a playing board, feature detector, and marker, then draws a feature card. Only aliens showing this feature live on the player's planet. Each player tries to find out the feature card that the other player drew.

On their turn, a player draws a face-down alien card and asks the other player if that alien lives on that player's planet. If the player says yes, the alien is placed on the first player's planet, if not, it is placed on the outer space area. The first player then crosses off any features that they can rule out on their feature detector, and it is the next player's turn.

Instead of their turn, a player can also guess the other player's secret feature. If they are right, they get a planet card and the round ends; if they are wrong, they lose a turn. At the end of a round, players wipe clean their feature detectors, shuffle the alien and feature cards, draw new feature cards and start another round.

The winner is the player who wins their fifth planet card.

In the advanced rules, two feature cards are drawn, and only aliens showing both features live on that planet, and the game finishes after one round.

1000 funny questions on the daily life and habits of the French!

The game takes place in 3 rounds. The first round candidates  submit questions, to keep his friends as close as possible to the correct answer. Candidates are then subjected to a second test: they must play as a team to the game "more or less" and restore their friend. Finally, comes the final round of the red carpet where you can multiply your winnings with each correct answer!

OPFOR Steel on Steel returns to the days of massed near-peer armies – but in contemporary times. The game pits the BLUFOR (U.S.) against OPFOR (World Class Opposing Forces).

In the game both players select appropriate combat and combat support units to capture key terrian. Each brigade area is then assigned a Mission Card for that battle sector. EAB (Echelons Above Brigade) units, from divisional units to air power, are drawn to give a hand of force multipliers. Combat and combat support cards are revealed to find initial strengths in each terrian sector. Mission cards are revealed to modify those strengths. Finally, EAB cards are played from the hand one card at a time in final attempts to win in each battle area.

The player who wins two of the three key terrian battle areas is the winner.

In Doomed you play a fallen angel who has sold its soul to Mephistopheles for a promise that was never repaid. Now you are exploring Hell to destroy the prince and take his throne.

You will face monsters, bosses, and Mephistopheles himself. In order to defeat monsters and escape events, you'll roll dice, with items, potions and skills boosting your chances of reaching Mephistopheles. Thankfully you're not alone when fighting against the boss as those are cooperative fights.

A wicked witch has cast her spell over the fairy-tale island and imprisioned the princess in a castle guarded by dragons. The way to the castle  is full adventure and danger. Only the magic shell, with its 12 shining pearls can give the princess the power to shed her bonds and remove the spell from the island. The player whoo succees in bringing the shell to the princess, after overcoming the dangers on the way with the help of the fairies, elves and other magic, becomes the ruler of the island.

This is a roll and move game where, at various points you can collect pearls or be forced to give them up. At points along the way, the player draws a card from various piles. The cards can be beneficial (magic or more pearls) or harmful (the witch card forces the player to give up pearls). The winner is the one who collects 12 pearls and reaches the princess first.

S.P.E.R.M.S. is a card game in which players play squads of commando sperm trying to battle and race each other to overcome Egg Defenses and be the first to reach the egg.

Players are dealt Position cards which indicate their respective progress towards the egg. On each player's turn, he must attack the player ahead of him, using a modified rock/paper/scissors combat system, that can result in players drawing cards, killing enemy soldiers, or switching positions with the other player. Players in first place instead "attack" an Egg Defenses deck, which functions in a push-your-luck fashion to either reward or punish the leader, and will eventually give up the winning egg card (several decoys must be uncovered first).

The game is full of puns, innuendoes, and adult humour.

128 cards. 4 pages of rules. 43 illustrations in full colour.

Solstice approaches. A swirling darkness coalesces in the night sky over a field as you, one of five Witches, perform incantations to vie for Earthly prominence, calling upon five Goddesses for protection and favor... But which of your fellow Witches serve the light, and which the dark? Gather information and form alliances, cast hexes, and use all your wit and connivance to ensure your dominance. Serve your Goddesses well, and they will reward you above their other followers, as they cast down those who dare to oppose them.

Coven is a game of secret alignments for 3-5 players in which each player represents a Witch serving either the darkness or the light. Not only is your starting alignment a secret, but each of the five non-player Goddesses has an unknown alignment as well. Deducing which Goddess(es) and which other player(s) share your alignment will make your strategy clear and victory easier to achieve, but not guaranteed by any means. Gameplay is deceptively simple, with five possible actions as players traverse a circular board with an inner pentagram rotating widdershins changing tactics with each rotation. Coven presents an interesting strategic challenge: the side (Light or Dark) that scores the most Balance defeats the opposing side — but on the dominating side, only the Witch that scores the most Power can win, so players must be careful not to invest too much in one while neglecting the other.

Coven includes five playable characters (along with their miniatures) – Witches of Earth, Water, Spirit, Air and Fire. The game also includes a Goddess Power/Balance board, Black and White magic crystals, hidden alignment tokens, "reversal" alignment crosses (for players who dare to change sides), Artifact Cards and Balance cards,  a Goddess Board,  and a two piece circular playing board with a rotating pentagram.

Knights of Ten is primarily a game for two, but can also be played by four competing in teams. You're trying to collect as much gold as possible each round, and the player (team) with the most gold after the predetermined number of rounds wins.

Each round, players start with seven cards in hand; cards feature numbers from 1 to 10, as well as negative numbers, cards that can be either positive or negative, and special plays such as the dragon and wizard. One player leads by playing a card to her "horde" (the table in front of her); if she plays a 1, she can play again immediately. The next player must follow – playing to his own horde first – and have an equal or higher total in his horde at the end of his turn. If he can't, he loses the trick; if he can, the opponent gets to play again and play continues back-and-forth until one player loses.

Whoever wins collects 1 gold, plus 1 Gold for each Gold card in the pot. The winner draws one card and either keeps it or keeps the next card in the deck; the loser draws two cards (one of them being the card left by the other player, if any). Play continues until all 16 Gold have been claimed, at which point a winner is determined for the round.

In a four-player game, you and your teammate share a horde and take turns playing into it.

From the publisher's website:

Zhukov's Final Victory is a low complexity level, two-player wargame on the battle for the capital of Nazi Germany, Berlin. In mid- April of 1945, Marshall Zhukov's 1st Byelorussian Front was poised and aimed like a dagger at the "Heart of the Fascist Beast" the city of Berlin, capital of Nazi Germany.

With thousands of tanks, artillery and soldiers available, the Russian Bear was determined to take the city and end the Great Patriotic War.

Konev's Gambit is an expansion game for Zhukov's Final Victory that extends play to include the offensive by Marshall Konev's 1st Ukrainian Front to take Berlin. Konev's Gambit is suited for two players, as well as solitaire play.

So here you get two games in one package.

Both games combined allows for three players as participants to take on the roles of the German Army and the two Soviet Front commanders. The Soviet players will be seeking to not only defeat their German opponent, but see who can be the first to capture Berlin. Looming over all players is the will of the supreme commanders on both sides: Hitler and Stalin. Can you do as well or better than your historical counterpart?

Game Components
Two, 11" x 17" map sections
120 double-sided unit counters
 12 Playing Cards
 One Player Aid Card
One, 8-page rule book

A game where three major powers of Europe (Great Britain, France, and Germany) attempt to create colonial Empires in Africa from 1882 to 1914.  The players lead each of these nations through the use of military units, civilian missions, and diplomats as they move about the African continent trying to gain control of various objectives.  The main international rivalries are: Anglo-German in conflict over Central Eastern Africa (Uganda and Kenya), Anglo-French conflict over the Nile Valley, and Franco-German conflict in Morocco and West Africa.

The winner of the game is the nation that gains most points for controling various regions of Africa through the following methods: using their diplomats to negotiate colonial treaties, establishing military cotnrol by having armies detachments occupy specific locations, or creating economic spheres of influence through use of civilian missions.

(This game is currently in prototype phase)

Constructing robots in a fully automated factory is quite a simple job, really. To be honest, it is such a bore that your abilities are hardly even challenged as the head of the robot assembly. Thus you make a bet with the other overseers at the robot assembly line: who can build the best robots the quickest? The loser will buy lunch oil for everyone. There IS the faint chance of someone falling down from the conveyor belts and getting scrapped. Fortunately, those unfortunate robots can be accounted for as collateral damage...

In Robot Factory, players guide their robots in a maze-like factory floor, using conveyor belts that keep moving every turn. Players operate their construction robots by playing programming cards, in an effort to collect parts for the most advanced robots as required by the given assembly instructions. Once a player has enough parts for assembly, they assemble the robots in the assembly lines and are awarded Victory Points. However, the players’ construction robots may be pushed off the board, and they only have a limited number of “lives” – CPU's – to reboot themselves after falling.

You want to gather all the parts, but so does everyone else. Keep your processor cool and tires on the belt! And Be Aware, this game will knock your Robo Block Off!!

Robot Factory features a pushable grid of tiles that makes the board change every player turn (similar mechanic in Labyrinth). The game packs an hour of fun game-play full of surprises, as players try to push each other off the board and new emerging tiles cause logistical challenges!

In Codon: The DNA Game, you are a student scientist competing against other scientists to determine the structure of five proteins involved in five common human diseases: cancer, AIDS, cystic fibrosis, muscular dystrophy, and diabetes. Each scientist player will roll the DNA Dice to identify the amino acids in these five human proteins. The scientist who identifies the most amino acids will earn the most points and win the game.

PiramiKa is a board game based chips in ancient Egyptian gods and culture.

At some point in the history of gaming chips Egyptians took shape and was born chess.

This game is an attempt to return the chips to a board where the chips are the Egyptian gods that depending on the nature of each god endow them with special powers.

The game flows out on a board where players can develop different strategies and should capture the god Ka / Ra to win the game.

But like in ancient Egypt, the Nile River has its importance random events creating different depending on the date provided by the board calendar, which is responsible for registering the course of days and nights of the week is up, which turn up the months of the year according to the ancient Egyptians saw, besides other event has been included as a force that is even above the gods who make up the game, this is Khepri the Egyptian scarab.

As in the game of chess mathematical possibilities are endless, but PiramiKa not a game of chess and each player can plan a strategy to capture the god Ra / Ka of his opponent in many different ways.

Battles are an important part of the game, various meetings with Khepri the beetle will have their importance if exceeded, each god may assert his power, but if he loses the game shall be removed and this battle can not be avoided, as to the battles between gods a balanced strategy can result in losing or winning the game.

On components of the game are easy to manufacture and this PnP version I included only black and white for anyone who wishes to try the game.

The game is complete and tested, with special care the balance between players and relation to the different components, a large development behind this game is based on the understanding the world who had the ancient Egyptians, as well as an equally important support in mathematics they used.

Definitely try to create a balanced game with a strong mathematical basis while the chance may frustrate the most brilliant strategic plans established by the players, so the perfect balance between them will win the player plus a proper strategic approach in as far as possible take into account the possibility that chance might hold both players during the course of the game.


PiramiKa es un juego de tablero que basa sus fichas en antiguos dioses egipcios y su cultura.

En algún momento de la historia las fichas de los juegos egipcios tomaron forma y nació el ajedrez.

Este juego es un intento por devolver las fichas a un tablero donde las fichas son dioses egipcios a los que dependiendo de la naturaleza de cada dios se les doto de poderes especiales.

El juego se trascurre en un tablero donde los jugadores podrán desarrollar diferentes estrategias y deberán capturar al dios Ka/Ra para ganar el juego.

Pero al igual que en el antiguo Egipto, el rió Nilo tendrá su importancia creando diferentes eventos aleatorios dependiendo de la fecha que proporciona el tablero calendario, que es el encargado de registrar el trascurso de días y noches de las que se componen las semanas, que a su vez componen los meses del año según los veían los antiguos egipcios, ademas otro evento ha sido incluido como una fuerza que esta incluso por encima de los dioses que componen el juego, este es Jepri el escarabajo egipcio.

Al igual que en el juego del ajedrez las posibilidades matemáticas son infinitas, pero PiramiKa no es un juego de ajedrez y cada jugador puede planear una estrategia para capturar al dios de Ra/Ka  de su oponente de muy diferentes formas.

Las batallas son una parte importante del juego, los diferentes encuentros con Jepri el escarabajo tendrán su importancia si es superada, cada dios podrá hacer valer su poder, pero si pierde deberá ser retirado del juego y esta batalla no podrá ser evitada, en cuanto a la batallas entre dioses una equilibrada estrategia puede dar como resultado el perder o ganar la partida.

Sobre los componentes del juego son de una fácil fabricación y en este PnP solo incluí la versión en blanco y negro para quien lo desee pueda probar el juego.

El juego esta completo y comprobado, cuide especialmente el equilibrio entre jugadores y relación con los diferentes componentes, hay un gran desarrollo detrás de este juego que está basado en la forma de entender el mundo que tenían los antiguos egipcios, así como un no menos importante apoyo en las matemáticas que utilizaron.

En definitiva intente crear un juego equilibrado con una importante base matemática a la vez que el azar puede malograr los más brillantes planes estratégicos establecidos por los jugadores, de esta forma el perfecto equilibrio entre ambos darán la victoria al jugador que además de un planteamiento estratégico correcto, en medida de lo posible tenga en cuenta las posibilidades que el azar pueda deparar a ambos jugadores durante el trascurso de la partida.

Objective: be the first player to reach the Check Out after collecting one grocery disc for each item on your shopping list
 - moving/acting by turn -
spin & move according to the number along the trail; you may move forward or backwards, but in one direction only;
collect grocery discs, spread on the trail (only those, which are on your list);
meeting another player (ending on the same space) you may pick one disc from him/her;

1969 is a push-your-luck style game in which players take the role of the leader of a particular nation's space program attempting the first successful lunar landing mission.

Each turn, the players use their income to hire scientists to research technology to improve their chances of success, hire spies to slow other players down, purchase cards to influence their missions and their competitors, or attempt easier, preparatory missions. Players gain victory points for performing well on prep missions, attracting famous scientists to their cause and, of course, how far they got on the Moon landing mission.
The core of the game are the mission tests, which consist of rolling five dice. Dice have success, neutral, and failure results, which add respectively to your success rating, do nothing, or subtract from it. The total of your successes will determine the points you earn from the mission and whether you'll get a bonus on the final lunar mission or not. Die rolls can be affected by technology and your success can be influenced by having scientists research relevant tech and by cards played by any player.

1969 combines simple dice mechanics with elements of resource management and even some light engine building to make an interesting lightweight experience. There are some mechanics of player interference (meaning players can disrupt each other's progress), but these elements can be avoided if desired.

In the modular game Countdown: Special Ops, you are in charge of a special ops team with a special mission! Find hidden bombs and dismantle them, help hostages into safety, or take out terrorist leaders. Due to the high variation in goals, targets, threats and specific circumstances, players need to choose their set-up and strategy each time they start a mission or a campaign. Don't just throw in grenades with your buster at public places such as airports and train stations, or else civilians might get hurt, resulting in negative points on your mission balance. (Plus, you know, injuring civilians is not cool.) Develop your primary skill, but don't neglect your attack power, defense power and other skills if you want to stay alive in this thrilling new game.

Countdown: Special Ops is fully modular, with players being able to create their own game by adjusting four different aspects of play:


     Game situations: With more than 200 playing cards, the challenges and threats are different each time you play.
     Game mode: You can play a single mission, a campaign or a scenario; each game mode has its own level and duration, and you're advised to start with a single mission on the lowest level (green).
     Level up: Did you succeed a few times on level green? If so, you might want to try the next (orange) level or even a scenario, that is, three missions in a row with increasing difficulty!
     Goals: Even players' goals can be altered. Countdown: Special Ops is a co-operative game, but if you'd like to change the rules, you could add one or two traitors to the team and play "Traitor Mode".


Development
You can develop your own Special Op by improving his or her skills. This is done in scenario or campaign play. This brings out interesting aspects of the game in which you have to choose how many risk you want to take to gain extra experience or if you want to move slow and stay alive at all cost...

This variation, combined with the 30-minute time limit per mission, makes the experience of a mission "feel" like an actual PC game in many aspects. Smart development is essential to survive the missions on higher threat levels.

A promotional Game by a regional newspaper for cultural attractions in the Rheinland region in the West of Germany.

Players roll a die and move a pawn along a track through the region "discovering it" by drawing and reading cards when they land on certain spaces.

Published in Game Market 2004.

The game is composed of 2 rounds.
In the first round, players bids to get his monster, its 4 attacks, its 3 defenses, its 2 special abilities and its 1 weakness.  Now, each player has his monster with 4 attacks and 3 defenses and 2 special abilities and 1 weakness.
In the second round, each player attack one of other monster in agility order.
The game ends when only one monster survive the second round.
